Much of the evolution of the Hominin clade has taken place in Africa, including Australopithecus, Homo habilis, and Homo sapiens until about 60,000 years ago. However there is increasing evidence that Homo sapiens arose in a broad swath of Africa including the drier more open landscapes of the Mediterranean (Jebel Irhoud Morocco 300,000 years ago), East Africa and South Africa. So it is possible, but doubtful that the very first humans arose in some non-African part of the Mediterranean. This seems doubtful, because the conditions to adapt to more open habitat certainly existed in Africa, and that is where the fossils are. An interesting earlier geographic note is that late Miocene apes (say 7 MYA) flourished in Europe and Asia. David Begun and some others think it possible that the earliest Hominini (human line as distinct from Panini, chimp line) arose say in Greece: Graecopithecus. The evidence is underwhelming for this particular genus. Graecopithecus - Wikipedia . But it is remarkable how common Miocene apes are outside of Africa. However later Hominins are all African until Homo erectus colonized Eurasia.
